comment: It's rather amazing to me that this opening variation should continue to be the primary defense of many top GMs. It was invented in the 1950s by Najdorf (originally of Poland, but after World War II of Argentina) and fought over throughout the 1960s and 70s. Bobby Fischer utilized it and honed it like a knife. Many years later, after other defenses have been tried and many discarded, this is Kasparov's favorite. It's interesting also to note that there are a zillion 6th moves White can choose from, and the one played most these days by the top GMs is 6. Be3, a move (and system) created by GM Robert Byrne, a New Yorker who was a childhood (and perhaps lifelong) friend of Bobby Fischer. Did he invent this opening variation to combat Fischer? I don't know. It was taken up by Englishmen and made more popular in the 1980s and 90s. Now it's commonplace.
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake made by the player by highlighting the historical significance and popularity of the opening variation, suggesting that its continued use by top players implies a belief in its effectiveness, despite the existence of numerous alternatives.

context: This is a game between Anand, Viswanathan (as White) and Kasparov, Garri (as Black). Last move played: Black plays Pawn to a6
reformulated: This opening move isn't particularly strong. It's a common choice for White, but it doesn't offer a strong advantage. The move was popularized by GM Robert Byrne in the 1980s and 90s, but it doesn't seem to be as effective as other options.

comment: Fischer preferred 6. Bc4 and that's still considered good, but it's not to the taste of today's players. I suppose I should also add that 6. Bg5 was "all the rage" during the 1960s and 70s when Fischer played actively, but his "Poison Pawn Variation" (after 6. Bg5 e6 7. f4 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2) is still considered good, and it's one reason 6. Bg5 isn't played much now.
reasoning: The comment correctly explains the mistake made by the player by highlighting the historical context and relevance of 6. Bg5, as well as the rarity of its current usage due to the popularity of Fischer's "Poison Pawn Variation".

reformulated: Fischer liked 6. Bc4, but it doesn't appeal to modern players. Also, 6. Bg5 was popular with Fischer in the '60s and '70s, but after the Poison Pawn Variation (6. Bg5 e6 7. f4 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2), it's less common now.

comment: Particularly against 6. Be2 this move (6...e5) was Fischer's response. It is named for Opocensky, but like many variations, Fischer played it a lot and made it popular. It makes sense that as White he'd play 6. Bc4 if he thought Black might play 6...e5, leaving the c4-f7 diagonal open.
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake by providing historical context and strategic reasoning behind the move, indicating that White could have anticipated Black's potential move and chosen a different strategy accordingly.

reformulated: In this game where Kasparov plays as Black and Anand as White, playing Pawn to e5, Fischer's choice of 6. Be2 is less common. Fischer might choose 6. Bc4 as it opens the c4-f7 diagonal against Black's potential 6...e5 move.

comment: White gains by having the open h-file, but Black retains sufficient control of the central squares. It's also less clear where White's king will be safe. After the king-side pawns advanced he wouldn't be expected to O-O, though he might play Ke1-f2. With Black's queen-side pawns far advanced it's highly unlikely he'll O-O-O. On the other hand, Black's king seems perfectly safe, but Rh8 is going to be out of play if Ke8 stays in the middle of that rank.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by White, as it highlights the potential disadvantages of advancing the king-side pawns, leaving the king unsafe, and the possibility of White being unable to castle.
